sen.j: 斑鳩神社（いかるがじんじゃ）は奈良県生駒郡の神社。
sen.e: Ikaruga-jinjya is a Shinto shrine in Ikoma-gun, Nara Prefecture.
Ikaruga-jinja Shrine is a Shinto shrine in Ikoma-gun, Nara Prefecture.
Ikaruga-jinja Shrine is a Shinto shrine in Ikoma-gun, Nara Prefecture.

sen.j: 法隆寺の北東の天満山に位置し、菅原道真を祀る。
sen.e: It is located in Mt. Tenma in the north east of Horyu-ji Temple and enshrines SUGAWARA no Michizane.
It is located on Mt. Tenma to the north east of Horyu-ji Temple and enshrines SUGAWARA no Michizane.
It is located on Mt. Tenma to the north east of Horyu-ji Temple and enshrines SUGAWARA no Michizane.

sen.j: 法隆寺鎮守神4社の1つで寺の鬼門の守護神とされ、現在も関係が深い。
sen.e: The shrine was one of the four chinju-sha shrine (Shinto shrine on Buddhist temple grounds dedicated to the tutelary deity of the area) of Horyu-ji Temple and regarded as a guardian god which protected against Kimon (the northeastern (unlucky) direction, person or thing to be avoided) for the temple, and even today, it has close ties to Horyu-ji Temple.

The shrine was one of the four chinju-sha shrines (Shinto shrine on Buddhist temple grounds dedicated to the tutelary deity of the area) of Horyu-ji Temple and regarded as a guardian god which protected against Kimon (the northeastern (unlucky) direction, person or thing to be avoided) for the temple, and even today, it has close ties to Horyu-ji Temple.

The shrine was one of the four chinju-sha shrines (Shinto shrine on Buddhist temple grounds dedicated to the tutelary deity of the area) of Horyu-ji Temple and regarded as a guardian god which protected against Kimon (the northeastern (unlucky) direction, person or thing to be avoided) for the temple, and even today, it has close ties to Horyu-ji Temple.
History
History
History

sen.j: 天慶年間に法隆寺の管主で菅原氏の湛照が創祀し、元亨4年（1324年）に僧・慶祐が社殿を造営したとの記録がある。
sen.e: There is a written record that during Tengyo era (938-947), Tansho, the chief priest of Horyu-ji Temple and member of SUGAWARA clan, first enshrined SUGAWARA no Michizane, then, a priest named Keiyu constructed the main building of the shirne in 1324.

There is a written record that during the Tengyo era (938-947), Tansho, the chief priest of Horyu-ji Temple and member of SUGAWARA clan, first enshrined SUGAWARA no Michizane before a priest named Keiyu constructed the main building of the shrine in 1324.

There is a written record that during the Tengyo era (938-947), Tansho, the chief priest of Horyu-ji Temple and member of Sugawara clan, first enshrined SUGAWARA no Michizane before a priest named Keiyu constructed the main building of the shrine in 1324.

sen.j: 当初は天満山の西麓に位置し境内に如法経堂という堂があったが、寛文年間に火災で全焼した。
sen.e: At first, the shrine was located in the west foot of Mt. Tenma and had a hall called Nyoho Kyodo (the Sutra Hall) in the precincts, but it was burned down during Kanbun era (1661-1672).
The shrine was originally located at the western base of Mt. Tenma and had a hall called Nyoho Kyodo (the Sutra Hall) in its precinct, but it was burned down during Kanbun era (1661-1672).
The shrine was originally located at the western base of Mt. Tenma and had a hall called Nyoho Kyodo (the Sutra Hall) in its precinct, but it was burned down during Kanbun era (1661-1672).

sen.j: 寛文8年（1668年）に神殿が再建された後、水害のため享保10年（1725年）に現在と同じ山上に移ったと伝えられる。
sen.e: It is said that after the reconstruction of the shirine building in 1668, it was moved to the top of the same mountain as it is today due to a flood disaster.
It is said that after the reconstruction of the shrine building in 1668, it was moved to the top of the same mountain where it stands today due to a flood disaster.
sen.cmt: as it is > where it stands
sen.e: It is said that after the reconstruction of the shrine building in 1668, it was moved to the top of the same mountain in 1725 where it stands today due to a flood disaster.

sen.j: 1869年（明治2年）には、法隆寺境内にあった総社明神、五所明神、白山権現が遷祀された。
sen.e: In 1869, Sosha Myojin God, Gosho Myojin God, and Hakusan Gongen deity, which used to be in the precincts of Horyu-ji Temple, were transferred to the shirine to be re-enshrined.
In 1869, Sosha Myojin, Gosho Myojin and Hakusan Gongen, which were enshrined in the precinct of Horyu-ji Temple, were transferred to the shrine to be re-enshrined.
In 1869, Sosha Myojin, Gosho Myojin and Hakusan Gongen, which were enshrined in the precinct of Horyu-ji Temple, were transferred to the shrine to be re-enshrined.

Shrine Buildings in the Precinct

sen.cmt: 文頭のみ大文字にしました。

sen.j: 総社明神：かつては法隆寺の北西にあり、仁平3年（1153年）に社殿を建立した。
sen.e: Sosha Myojin God used to be in the north west of Horyu-ji Temple, the building of which was constructed in 1153.
Sosha Myojin used to be enshrined to the northwest of Horyu-ji Temple, the building of which was constructed in 1153.
Sosha Myojin used to be enshrined to the northwest of Horyu-ji Temple, the building of which was constructed in 1153.

sen.j: 五所明神：建保6年（1218年）の創祀とされる法隆寺東院の総鎮守で、住吉神・春日神4座を祀る。
sen.e: Gosho Myojin Gods are the Grand Gardian Gods of Toin (East Precinct) of Horyu-ji Temple which are said to have been first enshirined in 1218, and the Gods enshrined there are Sumiyoshi God and 4 Kasuga Gods.

Gosho Myojin are the Grand Guardian Gods of Toin (East Precinct) of Horyu-ji Temple which are said to have been first enshrined in 1218, and the Gods enshrined there are Sumiyoshi God and four Kasuga Gods.

Gosho Myojin are the Grand Guardian Gods of Toin (East Precinct) of Horyu-ji Temple which are said to have been first enshrined in 1218, and the Gods enshrined there are Sumiyoshi God and four Kasuga Gods.

sen.j: 『延喜式神名帳』にある平群郡の平群神社五座に比定する説もある。
sen.e: There is also a theory that Gosho Myojin Gods were identified as five Gods of Heguri-jinjya Shrine located in Heguri-gun in "Engishiki jimmyocho (a register of shrines in Japan)".
There is also a theory that Gosho Myojin were identified as five Gods of Heguri-jinjya Shrine located in Heguri-gun in "Engishiki jimmyocho (a register of shrines in Japan)".
There is also a theory that Gosho Myojin were identified as five Gods of Heguri-jinja Shrine located in Heguri-gun in "Engishiki jinmyocho" (a register of shrines in Japan).

sen.j: 奈良県山添村室津の観音堂の鰐口は元は斑鳩神社のもので、永享9年（1437年）の銘がある。
sen.e: Waniguchi (a metal gong hanging at the front of hall in a temple) in Kanno-do hall located in Murotsu, Yamazoe-mura, Nara Prefecture originally belonged to Ikaruga-jinjya Shrine, and it has an inscription of the year 1437.

The waniguchi (a metal gong hanging at the front of hall in a temple) in Kanno-do hall located in Murotsu, Yamazoe-mura, Nara Prefecture originally belonged to Ikaruga-jinjya Shrine, and it has an inscription of the year 1437.
